Dear Mr. McCree:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
Title books, records, and reports.
Rule Code & Public Act 116 722.120
Section (c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the department,
Description and encouraging witnesses, such as staff and household
members, to provide accurate and truthful information to the
department.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff have been told what to say to investigators by management
at the facility.
Investigation Attempts were made to interview the Complainant on
09/23/2024, 10/25/2024 and 12/06/2024 and return contact was
not successful.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1
on 09/23/2024 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the
facility. She expressed no concerns that any staff had been
coached when investigations and interviews needed to occur.
Facility Manager 1 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS
Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
She did not feel there had ever been any instances of being
coached or told what to say for investigations. She noted that a
part of initial staff training was that investigations would occur, and
staff were always encouraged to tell the truth and participate fully
in them.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker
1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
reported no concerns with feeling pressured or told what to say for
investigations or Licensing purposes.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 1
stated he was aware of DHHS staff having to come to the facility
for investigations but that he was never aware when that was
occurring while he was on shift. Staff 1 denied ever being
coached on what to say while participating in an investigation.
2

Staff 2 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
denied ever being told what to say during a possible investigation.
Staff 1 also referred to training when she had first been hired
about needing to participate in similar interviews and being told to
tell the truth.
Staff 3 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
reported never feeling like he was pressured or coached on how
to participate in investigative interviews.
Facility Manager 2 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS
Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
She reported no concerns and had always been taught to just
answer questions as they are asked when having to participate in
investigations.
Staff 4 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
reported never being coached or told what to say for
investigations.
Staff 5 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
stated there were no times when she had been told what to say
for an investigative interview.
Staff 6 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She had no
concerns to report and never felt coached or told what to say.
Training Manager 1 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS
Worker 1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
He had never been told what to say for investigative purposes.
He remarked that part of initial employee training involved telling
them that these instances would happen at times and staff were
always supported in telling the truth.
Staff 7 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She never
experienced someone telling her what to say during an
investigation.
3

Supervisor 2 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker
1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
Supervisor 2 reported never being instructed on what to say when
participating in an investigation.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker
1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
reported never being told what to say for investigative purposes.
Staff 8 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She did not
feel that she was ever pressured or coached on what to say for an
investigation interview.
Staff 9 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
believed she had heard of other staff being told what to say for an
investigative interview but could not provide any further details of
who or when this occurred. Staff 9 noted that she heard this
second hand and thought it was a rare occurrence.
Supervisor 6 was interviewed over the phone on 10/17/2024.
She confirmed she was no longer employed by the facility as of a
few weeks prior. She stated there were times when staff were told
what to say by supervision for investigative interviews at the
facility. Supervisor 6 provided an instance where she felt coached
by another supervisor during an investigation because she was
told to describe an incident as “chaotic”. When asked for more
detail, Supervisor 6 stated that the incident itself was chaotic.
During a video call on 11/18/2024 DHHS Worker 1 stated that
they could not provide an update at that time of their investigative
findings.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff interviews. There
was no evidence found that any staff have “coached” any other
staff in order to tell them what to say during an investigation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation In September 2024 keys were taken away from staff, not allowing
them to open and secure doors as necessary.
Investigation The Chief Administrator was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1
on 09/23/2024 over the phone. She described a new process
within the facility where changes had been made to how keys and
unlocking doors was being handled. A new position had been
created named Safety Security Coordinator (SSC) and this role
was responsible for handling keys and unlocking doors as
necessary. While youth are in the pods, these staff remain in the
control room that oversees the two separate pods, allowing them
to respond to any needed situation. This new process took keys
and the responsibilities associated with them away from the Youth
Workers. The Chief Administrator described the newly titled staff
as able to open any door that is necessary at any time, and their
role was to remain available and alert to any needed situations.
She stated the implementation of this new procedure was not met
well by some staff, and she understood concern expressed that
the SSCs were not as available to timely responding to any
assistance needed by Youth Workers. The Chief Administrator
noted there had been no changes made to any secure aspects of
the program as a result of this new procedure. She also reported
the procedure had not yet been written into policy.
Facility Manager 1 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS
Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
She described the new process for staff handling keys within the
facility in a similar manner to the Chief Administrator. Facility
Manager 1 did not report any concerns that keys had been “taken
away” from all staff, just that it had been adjusted as to who was
responsible for them.
5

Staff 2 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
reported that no Youth Workers such as herself had keys
anymore. The staff that did have keys now were Managers,
Therapists and Safety Security Coordinators. Staff 2 expressed
concern over the ability for Safety Security Coordinators to report
timely when needed, but did not have any specific situations to
describe.
Youth B was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
remarked that staff do have keys, but he noticed the change
because he often had to wait with Youth Care Workers for
Supervisors or other staff to come with keys to unlock doors when
necessary.
Staff 9 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
described the same recent procedural change in who handles
keys and confirmed that there are staff with keys but expressed
concern that they were not always as available as they could be to
respond when needed.
The Licensee Designee was interviewed over the phone on
01/24/2025. He confirmed that written policy & procedure
regarding the use and responsibility of keys for staff within the
program was not yet available. Since the time of implementation,
the procedure has been adjusted several times. He stated the
original changes were addressed by himself during a staff meeting
in September 2024.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews with staff and
youth. There was no evidence found that no staff have keys
available within the secure facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty
to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency's program statement
and to provide for the continual needs, protection, and
supervision of residents
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Three youth were identified as having vape pens while at the
facility. It was alleged that these vape pens were provided to
them by Staff 2.
Investigation The Chief Administrator was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1
on 09/23/2024 over the phone. She reported she had been
informed that Youth E had a vape pen in his possession the prior
Thursday. The Chief Administrator confirmed that the vape pen
had been confiscated. In the process of doing so staff were not
able to figure out where Youth E had gotten the vape pen. The
Chief Administrator had not been presented any concerns that the
youth got this vape pen from a staff member.
An attempt was made to interview Youth A with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility on
09/26/2024. Youth A refused to interview.
Facility Manager 1 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS
Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
She reported Staff 3 had not reported to her that there was
concern that Youth E had gotten a vape pen from any staff
members. She stated she knew about the vape pen incident and
that it had been confiscated from Youth E. Facility Manager 1 had
no other information to share about this incident.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker
1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
Supervisor 1 recalled Staff 3 reporting to him concern that Youth E
had a vape in his possession. Supervisor 1 confirmed he was a
part of the effort to search Youth E’s room. He stated a vape was
found hidden in Youth E’s room, and Youth E had consistently
denied speaking to how he had it after that occurred.
7

Staff 2 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 2
denied the allegations that she provided a vape to any youth
within the facility. She stated she does not use nicotine and had
never brought anything like that to the facility. Staff 2 believed
Youth E had told Supervisor 3 he had a vape in his bedroom, but
Staff 2 could not elaborate on how she knew that when she was
not a part of that conversation. Staff 2 was aware Youth E had a
vape confiscated from him. She stated she had not had much
contact with Youth E because she generally worked on another
pod.
Staff 3 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
recalled being with Youth A on one occasion in a pod during some
down time and the two were playing cards. Youth A commented
to Staff 3 that Staff 2 was going to get a vape pen for him and
Youth E. Staff 3 stated he reported this concern to Supervisor 1.
Staff 3 also recalled hearing Youth C talk about being able to have
a vape pen within the facility. Staff 3 was involved the next day
with the effort to retrieve and confiscate a vape pen from Youth E.
Staff 3 believed it was Facility Manager 1 that had spoken with
Youth E about the vape pen and that he stated to her Staff 2 had
provided it to him.
Staff 4 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 4
recalled attempting to confiscate the vape pen from Youth E and
how that came to be. Staff 4 stated there was a recent instance
when Staff 5 asked if she could speak specifically with Facility
Manager 1. Staff 5 stated she wanted to report concerns that
Youth E had a vape pen. Staff 4 asked Staff 5 how she knew this,
and Staff 5 would not say. Staff 4 saw Youth E that same day and
asked him if he had a vape pen in the facility, and Youth E denied
this. Staff 4 was then a part of several staff that searched Youth
E’s room and person and confiscated the vape pen. Youth E
continuously denied speaking on where he obtained the vape pen.
Staff 5 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
recalled an instance when Youth E was on the pod alone and she
was in the control room. She believed she saw him reach down in
to his pants and pull something out that was in a sock, and then
proceeded to blow a small amount of smoke out of his mouth.
Staff 5 stated she called him out to see what he was doing, and in
8

his already escalated state he yelled back and threatened her.
Staff 5 recalled then telling Staff 4 about what she had seen, and
then reporting it up to Facility Manager 1. Staff 5 clarified she did
not provide the vape to Youth E and only witnessed this brief
instance of him allegedly using it. Staff 5 knew that a vape had
been confiscated from Youth E and did not know how he obtained
it.
Training Manager 1 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS
Worker 1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
He recalled staff members coming to him to report concerns that
Youth E had a vape, but they were all second had. Training
Manager 1 recalled participating in conversations shortly
thereafter about how to confiscate that item from the youth.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker
1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
reported being a part of the staff that confiscated the vape pen
from Youth E. Supervisor 2 had no knowledge as to where Youth
E procured that vape pen, and he did not have any concern that it
was provided to him by staff. Supervisor 2 believed that Youth E
most likely smuggled in the vape pen from a home pass some
time in the past.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker
1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
recalled an instance when Youth E had reported to him directly he
had a vape pen at the facility. Supervisor 3 recalled him stating
“Yeah, I have one. So what?” Supervisor 3 reported informing his
peers and they came up with a plan to attempt to confiscate this
item from Youth E. Supervisor 3 stated that at no point in time did
Youth E give any indication as to who gave him the vape or if he
brought it into the facility himself.
Documents reviewed:
• Incident report documentation dated 09/19/2024 was
provided and reviewed. This documentation outlined the
incident where a vape was confiscated from Youth E’s
person. At no point in this documentation did Youth E
provide any information as to where the vape came from.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews. There was no evidence found that youth have been
provided vapes by staff at the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

Rule Code Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
Title required.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4131
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
Description assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238,
MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff become "targets" and experience negative repercussions as
a result of reporting concerns.
Investigation Facility Manager 1 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS
Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
She reported no concerns about having any retribution or negative
consequences occur as a result of her expressing concerns within
the facility.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker
1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
stated feeling comfortable expressing concerns within the facility
and had not felt any negative consequences for doing so.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
reported never feeling any negative consequences for reporting
concerns.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
believed concerns she had shared with management had not
been addressed properly. She also stated she had received an
“attitude” from managers. She detailed an instance when Training
Manager 1 had asked her to come back after a shift to finish some
of her official training, only to be sent home again and have to
come back another day. Staff 2 believed there was personal
intent behind that decision but could not connect this to any
possible retribution for concerns she had expressed. Another
example Staff 2 referenced occurred the day prior where Staff 7
had sent Staff 2 home for violating the program’s dress code.
Staff 2 believed she had reported something negative about Staff
7 at some point in time but could not specify what that was.
10

Staff 3 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 3
did not believe anything like retribution had occurred to him in his
time working at the facility. He believed that it may have occurred
to a past co-worker that was frequently mandated to work extra
shifts, but he could not provide any other details.
Facility Manager 2 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS
Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
She reported never feeling negative consequences were placed
on her as a result of raising concerns within the facility.
Staff 4 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
reported not feeling targeted or experiencing negative
consequences for reporting concerns.
Staff 5 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
stated she felt comfortable reporting concerns without negative
consequences that could come her way.
Staff 6 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
reported no concerns on negative consequences for reporting
concerns.
Training Manager 1 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS
Worker 1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
He stated that he has never felt negative consequences for
reporting concerns. He was aware of the situation described by
Staff 2 and stated that was solely a misunderstanding of
scheduling and had nothing to do with any concerns reported by
Staff 2, of which he was unaware of any.
Staff 7 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 7 felt
that she never experienced repercussions as a result of reporting
concerns. She recalled the instance when Staff 2 had to go home
and change, and Staff 7 reported this was strictly because of
dress code policy for the facility and had nothing to do with
anything else.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker
1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He had no
11

concerns that staff experienced negative consequences for
reporting concerns about things going on at the facility.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker
1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
reported never experiencing repercussions for reporting concerns,
and did not believe this had ever occurred for any other staff.
Staff 8 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 8 did
not believe there were any negative consequences that occurred
because staff ever reporting negative things occurring at the
facility.
Staff 9 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 9
reported no concerns of being target as a result of expressing
concerns.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff interviews. There
was no evidence found that staff have received negative
repercussions for expressing concerns about anything going on in
the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty
to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency's program statement
and to provide for the continual needs, protection, and
supervision of residents
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A was physically assaulted by other youth and Supervisor 5
was supposed to be supervising and intervening.
Investigation An attempt was made to interview Youth A with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth A
refused to interview.
12

Staff 4 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
believed he could recall the incident described in the allegations.
Staff 4 recalled being with Youth A outside of the gym when two
different pods and their associated staffs crossed paths exiting
and entering the gym. As this occurred two or three youth with the
pod that was exiting the gym ran back in to fight Youth A. Staff 4
recalled Supervisor 5 being among the staff that helped break up
that fight as it started.
At the time when this intake was received, Supervisor 5 was no
longer employed by the facility. Attempts were made to interview
Supervisor 5 on 10/17/2024 and 12/06/2024 with no return
contact.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews. There was no evidence found that Supervisor 5 was
not supervising Youth A properly, resulting in Youth A being
abused by other youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention;
Title prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (2) The following restraints are strictly prohibited:
Description (g) Peer-on-peer discipline or utilizing the assistance of
another youth to implement a restraint.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff allowed Youth C and Youth E to restrain Youth D during an
incident. No date was provided for the incident.
Investigation Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker
1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
could not recall the incident in question, but did state he did not
believe that youth were able to restrain other youth during
incidents. Supervisor 1 described basic de-escalation training
including the need to ensure all non-involved youth be separated
and moved away from a situation. He stated it was common for
youth to attempt to calm down other youth. Supervisor 1 noted
13

that youth were not allowed to touch each other and if they went
hands on with each other staff always intervened to separate
them.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 09/26/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
recalled being alone with Youth C, Youth D and Youth E on the
pod. Youth D then got upset and began to try to break door
handles. Staff 2 recalled needing a Safety Security Coordinator to
come assist and keep him out of a broom closet. Youth D then
began to pull on a pipe, and Staff 2 recalled Youth C and Youth E
then trying to stop him from doing so. Staff 2 stated she
attempted to keep Youth C and Youth E off of Youth D but was
not initially successful in doing so. Staff 2 stated Youth D
eventually calmed down and no one had their hands on him. She
could not recall exactly when this incident occurred.
Youth B was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He was not
aware of the specific situation noted in the allegation, but he did
believe there were times when youth attempted to restrain other
youth. Youth B did not have any specific examples to describe.
He did describe situations where he has seen youth attempt to
break up fights and put their hands on each other, which they are
not allowed to do, only for staff to regularly intervene verbally and
physically.
Youth C was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth C
recalled the situation where he was allegedly restrained by other
youth. Youth C stated it all began when Youth D was upset, and
Youth C tried to talk him down. Youth C believed he tried to hold
Youth D back from getting into the control room, and that a staff
member told him to “make sure he doesn’t go into the control
room.” Youth C could not clarify if he had his hands on Youth D at
that point in time, or who the staff was that stated this to him.
Youth C remarked that escalated physical incidents occur at the
facility often, and when multiple youth are involved, staff often tell
youth to back away and instruct them to not go hands on or
attempt to restrain other youth.
Youth D was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth D
described the incident in question as “just playing around” and
denied that he was restrained by anyone. Youth D had no other
clarifying information to offer.
14

Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews. There was no evidence found that any youth have
been allowed by staff to restrain other youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited
to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to
a youth's background or appearance or mental state.
Yelling, threats, ridicule, or humiliation are strictly
prohibited.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff 8 has sworn at the residents while providing direction to
them.
Investigation Staff 8 was interviewed on 10/03/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 8
recalled a recent instance where she did use swear words when
communicating with the youth in the pod where she was working.
Staff 8 recalled a few youth escalating verbally as they moved
towards bed time. Staff 8 was called a “bitch” and she cussed
